results.title: You can do it!
results.brief_description: Based on the book by Michael E. Bernard. This video is designed to aid students (and others) in developing the skills and essential attitudes necessary for success in school and happiness in life. The video addresses issues such as goal setting, time management, attitudes, self-confidence, self-motivation, exam anxiety and relationships.

results.title: You can do anything
results.creator_credit: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler
results.brief_description: The Kirinara Hostel in N.S.W. offers an educational program specifically designed for young Aboriginal and Islander people. The video focuses on students at the hostel and includes interviews with ex-students who have pursued careers in a diverse range of fields including law, teaching, football and dance. The graduates stress the importance of individuals setting realistic goals for themselves as well as the need for Aboriginal education support schemes to assist young Aboriginal people to achieve their full educational potential.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Australia. Dept. of Employment, Education and Training, Film Australia and Aviva Ziegler

results.title: You can't always tell
results.creator_credit: Terry Jennings, Chrysalis Films and Scott Hicks
results.brief_description: This film aims to inform children in the seven to twelve age group of the problem of child molesting. It contains a series of dramatised scenes showing situations in which children can find themselves. Shows children how to avoid putting themselves at risk with strangers.

results.title: You are what you eat
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nutrition”.
Six lively programs hosted by Liza Goddard which offer information and practical advice on how to dramatically improve health by altering eating habits. Although aimed at British adults the programs are short and pacy and very relevant to Australian adolescents and adults. The contents are: “Food for life: how to include more fibre, fruit, vegetables and fish”, “Go with the grain: re-educating children to eat more grain”, “Don’t eat your heart out: reducing fats in the diet”, “Sweet nothing: try to eliminate sugar which provides no nourishment”, “Pinch of chemicals: manufactured goods contain additives, preservatives and salt”, “Food in the fast lane: simple suggestions for nourishing packed lunches and fast foods”.

results.title: You are what you eat
results.creator_credit: William C. Crain, Becky Bristow and Barr Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Nutrition”.
Animated sequences explore this theme, while two voices discuss the significance of each scene. They explain the importance of choosing food from all of the basic food groups to provide a balanced diet. They also explain how proteins, carbohydrates, fats, vitamins, and minerals are used in our bodies, how digestion changes the food we eat so our bodies can use the nutrients, and how exercise and rest are needed to help us grow strong and healthy.
results.creator_credit_for_label: William C. Crain, Becky Bristow and Barr Films

results.title: You are welcome sirs, to Cyprus
results.brief_description: A view of the troubled island of Cyprus from the point of view of Canadian soldiers of the United Nations peace force who were called upon to help keep the peace until agreement could be reached between the Greek and Turkish factions. General Thimayya of India, commander of the UN troops, explains his responsibility. Among the Cypriots who appear in this film are Archbishop Makarios and Dr Kutchuk, the Turkish vice-president. Commentary by Jos Reeve.

results.title: You are on Indian land
results.creator_credit: George C. Stoney and ONF | NFB
results.brief_description: A film report of the 1969 protest demonstration by Mohawk Indians of the St. Regis Reserve on the international bridge between Canada and the United States near Cornwall, Ontario. By blocking the bridge, which is on the Reserve, and causing a considerable tie-up of motor traffic, the Indians drew public attention to their grievance that they were prohibited by Canadian authorities from duty-free passage of personal purchases across the border; a right they claim was established by the Jay Treaty of 1794. The film shows the confrontation with police, and ensuing action. (Awards: New York; Toronto.)
